title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
added: Several sites and individuals published predictions of competitive seats. These predictions looked at factors such as the strength of the [[incumbent]] (if the incumbent is running for re-election), the strength of the candidates, and the partisan leanings of the state (reflected in part by the state's [[Cook Partisan Voting Index]] rating). The predictions assigned ratings to each seat, with the rating indicating the predicted advantage that a party has in winning that seat.
* "<u>tilt</u>" (used by some predictors): advantage that is not quite as strong as "lean"

In many cases the incumbent has yet to say their intention of running for another term. If an incumbent intends to retire then place "
{{Small|(retiring)}}" after the incumbent's name.
See [[Template:USRaceRating]] for how to apply rating.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: ![[Cook Partisan Voting Index|PVI]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://decisiondeskhq.com/news/2016-state-pvi-changes|title=2016 State PVI Changes – Decision Desk HQ|website=decisiondeskhq.com|date=December 15, 2017|access-date=December 11, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180613111559/https://decisiondeskhq.com/news/2016-state-pvi-changes/|archive-date=June 13, 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref>
!Incumbent<ref>Parentheses around an incumbent's name indicates that the incumbent is retiring, possibly due to term limits.</ref>

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Arizona|Governor]] [[Doug Ducey]] was re-elected to a second term in [[2018 Arizona gubernatorial election|2018]] with 56% of the vote. He will be [[Term limits in the United States|term-limited]] by the [[Arizona Constitution]] in 2022 and cannot seek election as governor until 2026.

Potential Republican candidates include [[Attorney General of Arizona]] [[Mark Brnovich]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Already playing politics for governor|url=https://www.myheraldreview.com/opinion/our_view/our-view-already-playing-politics-for-governor/article_f97f92d0-ba2c-11ea-a2c2-3ffae1578e36.html|website=[[Herald/Review]]|date=June 29, 2020|access-date=October 25, 2020}}</ref> U.S Representative [[David Schweikert]],<ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. Rep. David Schweikert floats run for Arizona governor in 2022|url=https://ktar.com/story/1804324/u-s-rep-david-schweikert-floats-run-for-arizona-governor-in-2022/|website=[[KTAR-FM|KTAR]]|date=October 26, 2017|access-date=October 25, 2020}}</ref> and [[State Treasurer of Arizona]] [[Kimberly Yee]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Roberts|first1=Laurie|title=Kimberly Yee is acting an awful lot like ... Doug Ducey. Is she setting herself up to replace him?|url=https://amp.delawareonline.com/story/opinion/op-ed/laurieroberts/2020/10/19/kimberly-yee-looks-like-she-wants-next-gov-doug-ducey/3681953001/|website=[[The News Journal|Delaware Online]]|date=October 19, 2020|access-date=October 25, 2020}}</ref>. Business Executive and 2020 Senate Candidate Daniel McCarthy<ref>{{cite tweet |user=DemandDanielAZ |number=1336380864893124608 |title=Jim, thank you! I am not a state Rep. State Reps have signed it, but I am setting up a run for Governor of Arizona. The source you republished got it wrong. I'll be on the War Room with Owen Shroyer around 4:30 ET to give the latest |date=December 8, 2020 |author=Daniel McCarthy |access-date=January 15, 2020}}</ref> has already expressed interest in running.

Democratic [[Secretary of State of Arizona]] [[Katie Hobbs]] has said that she's seriously considering a campaign, and has given a decision timetable of early 2021. Other potential Democratic candidates include [[Arizona House]] Minority Leader [[Charlene Fernandez]], and U.S Representative [[Greg Stanton]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Herstam|first1=Chris|title=Katie Hobbs for governor – already?|url=https://www.azmirror.com/2020/01/06/monday-musings-all-eyes-on-how-sinema-handles-impeachment/|website=[[The Times-Gazette]]|date=January 6, 2020|access-date=October 25, 2020}}</ref>

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Arkansas|Governor]] [[Asa Hutchinson]] was re-elected to a second term in [[2018 Arkansas gubernatorial election|2018]] with 65.3% of the vote. He will be [[Term limits in the United States|term-limited]] by the [[Arkansas Constitution]] in 2022 and cannot seek re-election for a third term. [[Lieutenant Governor of Arkansas|Lieutenant Governor]] [[Tim Griffin]], former [[White House Press Secretary]] and the daughter of former [[Arkansas]] governor [[Mike Huckabee]] [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]], and [[Arkansas Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[Leslie Rutledge]] have announced campaigns, although Griffin eventually dropped out of the race and decided to run for Attorney General instead. <ref>{{cite web | access-date=2021-01-02 | url=https://www.kait8.com/2019/08/05/lt-gov-tim-griffin-says-hes-running-arkansas-governor/ | title=Lt. Gov. Tim Griffin says he's running for Arkansas governor | language=en-US | website=www.kait8.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-07-01|title=Arkansas' attorney general says she's running for governor|url=https://apnews.com/article/e37ae8f845863addef904afd94409d8c|access-date=2021-01-02|website=AP NEWS}}</ref>

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of California|Governor]] [[Gavin Newsom]] was elected in [[2018 California gubernatorial election|2018]] with 61.9% of the vote. He is eligible to run for re-election, but has not yet stated whether he will do so.

deleted: [[Governor of Colorado|Governor]] [[Jared Polis]] was elected in [[2018 Colorado gubernatorial election|2018]] with 53.4% of the vote. He is eligible to run for re-election, but has not yet stated whether he will do so.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Connecticut|Governor]] [[Ned Lamont]] was elected in [[2018 Connecticut gubernatorial election|2018]] with 49.4% of the vote. He is eligible to run for re-election, but has not yet stated whether he will do so. [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee for governor in [[2018 Connecticut gubernatorial election|2018]] [[Bob Stefanowski]] may run against Lamont again.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Vigdor|first=Neil|title=The once and future candidate? Republican Bob Stefanowski transforms from losing nominee to ubiquitous foil of Gov. Ned Lamont|url=https://www.courant.com/politics/hc-pol-stefanowski-still-campaigning-20190528-3ivzcnv7u5ftzmq5y2d4wgxefy-story.html|access-date=2021-02-04|website=courant.com}}</ref>

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Hawaii|Governor]] [[David Ige]] was re-elected to a second term in [[2018 Hawaii gubernatorial election|2018]] with 62.7% of the vote. He will be [[Term limits in the United States|term-limited]] from the [[Hawaii Constitution]] in 2022 and cannot seek re-election for a third consecutive term.

deleted: [[Governor of Illinois|Governor]] [[J. B. Pritzker]] was elected in [[2018 Illinois gubernatorial election|2018]] with 54.5% of the vote. He is eligible to run for re-election, but has not yet stated whether he will do so.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Kansas|Governor]] [[Laura Kelly]] was elected in [[2018 Kansas gubernatorial election|2018]] with 48% of the vote. She plans to run for re-election.<ref>https://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/election/article247950295.html</ref>

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Maine|Governor]] [[Janet Mills]] was elected in [[2018 Maine gubernatorial election|2018]] with 50.9% of the vote. She is eligible to run for re-election, but has not yet stated whether she will do so. Former [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Governor of Maine|governor]] [[Paul LePage]] has announced that he will run again.<ref>{{cite news|title=Paul LePage says 'I am going to challenge Janet Mills' in 2022|url=https://bangordailynews.com/2020/04/29/politics/paul-lepage-says-i-am-going-to-challenge-janet-mills-in-2022/|access-date=April 29, 2020|newspaper=[[Bangor Daily News]]|date=April 29, 2020}}</ref>

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Nevada|Governor]] [[Steve Sisolak]] was elected in [[2018 Nevada gubernatorial election|2018]] with 49.4% of the vote. He is eligible to run for re-election, but has not yet stated whether he will do so.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of New Mexico|Governor]] [[Michelle Lujan Grisham]] was elected in [[2018 New Mexico gubernatorial election|2018]] with 57.2% of the vote. She is eligible to run for re-election, but has not yet stated whether she will do so.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of New York|Governor]] [[Andrew Cuomo]] was re-elected to a third term in [[2018 New York gubernatorial election|2018]] with 59.6% of the vote. Because [[New York (state)|New York]] does not have gubernatorial term limits in its [[New York Constitution|Constitution]], he is eligible to run for re-election for a fourth term. On May 28, 2019, Cuomo announced that he would run for re-election for a fourth term in 2022.<ref name="thehill1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/andrew-cuomo-says-hell-run-for-fourth-term-as-governor/ |title=Andrew Cuomo says he'll run for fourth term as New York governor |work=CBS News |date=May 28, 2019 |access-date=May 13, 2020}}</ref>

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Oregon|Governor]] [[Kate Brown]] took office on February 18, 2015 upon the resignation of [[John Kitzhaber]]. She was subsequently elected in the gubernatorial special election in [[2016 Oregon gubernatorial special election|2016]] and was re-elected to a full term in [[2018 Oregon gubernatorial election|2018]] with 50.1% of the vote. She will be [[Term limits in the United States|term-limited]] by the [[Oregon Constitution]] in 2022 and cannot seek re-election for another full term until 2026.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Pennsylvania|Governor]] [[Tom Wolf]] was re-elected to a second term in [[2018 Pennsylvania gubernatorial election|2018]] with 57.8% of the vote. He will be [[Term limits in the United States|term-limited]] from the [[Pennsylvania Constitution]] in 2022 and will therefore be unable to seek re-election for a third consecutive term. Potential Democratic candidates include former state treasurer [[Joe Torsella]], state attorney general [[Josh Shapiro]] and Philadelphia mayor [[Jim Kenney]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Brennan |first1=Chris |last2=Terruso |first2=Julia |last3=McCrystal |first3=Laura |title=Did Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Wolf just endorse Josh Shapiro for governor in 2022? 'That's my guy.' |url=https://www.inquirer.com/politics/clout/clout-hot-seat-tom-wolf-josh-shapiro-jim-kenney-joe-torsella-2022-race-governor-20191108.html |publisher=Philly.com |date=November 8, 2019}}</ref>

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Rhode Island|Governor]] [[Gina Raimondo]] was re-elected to a second term in [[2018 Rhode Island gubernatorial election|2018]] with 52.6% of the vote. She will be [[Term limits in the United States|term-limited]] from the [[Rhode Island Constitution]] in 2022 and cannot seek re-election for a third consecutive term. She was selected by [[Joe Biden]] to serve as the [[Secretary of Commerce]] and pending confirmation, will be seated at some point after January 20, 2021.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Wisconsin|Governor]] [[Tony Evers]] was elected in [[2018 Wisconsin gubernatorial election|2018]] with 49.5% of the vote. He is eligible to run for re-election, but has not yet stated whether he will do so.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
deleted: [[Governor of Guam|Governor]] [[Lou Leon Guerrero]] was elected in [[2018 Guamanian gubernatorial election|2018]] with 50.8% of the vote. She is eligible to run for reelection.

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections

title: 2022 United States gubernatorial elections
added: Election outlets currently rate [[2022 Arizona gubernatorial election|Arizona]], [[2022 Georgia gubernatorial election|Georgia]], [[2022 Kansas gubernatorial election|Kansas]], [[2022 Maryland gubernatorial election|Maryland]], and [[2022 Pennsylvania gubernatorial election|Pennsylvania]] as the most likely tossup states.
